title: Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Streamgraph of adaptation finance
sections:
Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Streamgraph of adaptation finance

This diagram presents the evolution of the international funds pledged and disbursed for adaptation in Bangladesh (according to the data of the website ClimateFundsUpdate - http://www.climatefundsupdate.org/). It shows how the expected funding has massively increased starting from 2010 (especially, but not exclusively because of the intervention of the Japanese ‘Fast Start Finance’). It also shows, however, that the greatest part of this funding has not yet been disbursed. The data have been extracted from the websites of different national and international institutions and have been manually cleaned and merged.

How to read the map

In the diagram each of the source of funding is represented with a stream whose thickness varies according to the cumulated amount of funds pledged (the white part stream) and disbursed by each source through the years.  

How the map is built (map building protocol)

This paragraph being the same for all the maps of this project, I have moved it in this file

title: Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Scatterplots of strategies, sectors, risks and funding source
sections:
Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Scatterplots of strategies, sectors, risks and funding source

These scatterplots present the distribution of adaptation funds and projects in Bangladesh according to the adaptation strategies employed, the sectors of intervention, the type of climate risk addressed and the sources of funding. On all dimensions, the diagrams show a clear concentration both in terms of amount of funds and number of projects. Issue related to forest and water related issues (droughts, sea level rise, rivers, cyclones) seem to play a particularly important role. The scatterplots are based on data extracted from the websites of different national and international institutions and have been manually cleaned and merged.

How to read the map

These four maps are basic scatterplots. Dots in the plots represent respectively the different adaptation strategies employed, the sectors of intervention, the type of climate risk addressed and the sources of funding.

The position X axis indicates the number of projects (for each adaptation strategy, sector, climate risk and funding source). The Y axis indicate the total amount of money invested.

The dots far from the diagonal (bottom-left  / top-right) are the most interesting because they contains projects that are better financed (above the diagonal) or worse financed (below the diagonal) than the average.

The dots in the angles are also interesting: the dots in the bottom-left angle represents ‘orphans categories’ (containing few projects and scarcely financed), while the the dots in the bottom-left angle represent ‘rich categories’ (containing many projects and well financed).

How the map is built (map building protocol)

This paragraph being the same for all the maps of this project, I have moved it in this file

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WD07nf_D1Gg-CcZ00m_PgD6Hn4xa4kLfJUmPWg53aBs/edit?usp=sharing

title: Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Treemaps of the distribution of funds and projects
sections:
Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Treemaps of the distribution of funds and projects

These treemaps present the distribution of adaptation projects in different divisions and district of Bangladesh. The data have been extracted from the websites of different national and international institutions and have been manually cleaned and merged.

How to read the map

These treemaps represent Bangladesh as a large rectangle whose surface is divided in smaller rectangles corresponding to the 7 divisions of the state. Each of these rectangles is in its turn divided in even smaller rectangles corresponding to the the different districts of Bangladesh. The surfaces of each rectangle is proportional to the population size of the corresponding region (division or district).

The shade of the color of the rectangles varies according to two different variables:

  • the number of adaptation projects to be implemented in each region (for figure 6)
  • the total amount of funds pledged for adaptation projects in each region (for figure 7)

How the map is built (map building protocol)

This paragraph being the same for all the maps of this project, I have moved it in this file

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WD07nf_D1Gg-CcZ00m_PgD6Hn4xa4kLfJUmPWg53aBs/edit?usp=sharing

title: Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Treemaps of the distribution of funds and projects
sections:
Adaptation Funding in Bangladesh - Distribution of fundings in Bangladesh, by risk and adaptation strategy.

This interactive visualization shows the distribution of the adaption fundings in Bangladesh across risks and adaptation strategies. In order to explore different aspects of the same dataset, user can choose in which step force the flow of adaption funds.

How to read the map

Above the map the user can choose which steps to incorporate into the visualization.

Four steps are available:

  • Funding Sources
  • Divisions of Bangladesh
  • Adaption Strategies
  • Risks

Each step is a distribution of the same amount of money (the total amount of funds for Bangladesh) across the related category. Inside of it, subdivisions are ordered from top to bottom by their own percentage of funds.

Once chosen them, the map automatically shows the flow of money from the first step to the last one. Each flow’s thickness is proportional to the amount of money, highlighting features and allowing users to compare different steps.

Please note that colors does not follow any proper chromatic scale.

How the map is built (map building protocol)

This paragraph being the same for all the maps of this project, I have moved it in this file

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WD07nf_D1Gg-CcZ00m_PgD6Hn4xa4kLfJUmPWg53aBs/edit?usp=sharing

title: how the map is built
sort: 02 how the map is built (all maps of this project)

title: metadata
sections:
Authors

Bernhard Rieder (Digital Methods Initiative, University of Amsterdam), Michele Mauri, Giovanni Magni (Density Design, Politecnico of Milano), Peter Gerry (Young Foundation), Sukaina Bharwani (weADAPT, Stockholm Environment Institute), Tom Turnbull (School of Geography and the Environment, University of Oxford),

Data time-stamp

EMAPS Oxford Sprint, 22-26 April 2014

Data sources

BCCTF (Bangladesh Climate Change Trust Fund) - http://www.moef.gov.bd/html/climate%20change%20unit/climate%20change%20unit.html 

BCCRF (Bangladesh Climate Change Resilience Fund) - http://www.bccrf-bd.org/ 

PKSF-CCCP (Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation Community Climate Change Project) - http://www.pksf-cccp-bd.org/ 

Climate Funds Update - http://www.climatefundsupdate.org/ 

WeAdapt - http://weadapt.org/ 

Data files

https://drive.google.com/open?id=1WwFHZs6sPdSQFs3_rJERzsEgCS4oajR1D4LrrEj4aOo&authuser=0 [a]

Code

In technical terms, the dashboard consists of a single file that uses the Google Spreadsheet API (https://developers.google.com/google-apps/spreadsheets/) to retrieve data directly from our aggregation spreadsheet. It then uses a number of modules from the Google Visualization Library (https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/visualization) to display the data in different ways.

Code: https://github.com/bernorieder/EMAPS-TAFIB[b]

Related narratives

Narrative 3: Tracking Adaptation in Bangladesh - https://docs.google.com/document/d/136M4Q1DoGrka5c2T2Xi_0QQSTlT_u6sDNDY4KXUF9mE/edit?usp=sharing 

Related maps

10b, 10c, ...

After consulting with our domain expert, we decide to complement the static maps available in this platform with an information dashboard that dynamically draws data from a Google spreadsheets that can be update by the experts on the ground.

The dashboard is available here http://labs.polsys.net/tools/tafib/ [c] 

[a]Requires some manual cleaning of the categorization

[b]Should be moved to the Github account of the EMAPS project

[c]The dashboard should be moved in the webspace of the platform as well as its data.

ATTENTION: for the moment the dashboard pulls its data from this address

https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1WwFHZs6sPdSQFs3_rJERzsEgCS4oajR1D4LrrEj4aOo/od6/public/basic

If the data are moved (as they probably should and will), this address will have to change.
